grab.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to take hold of someone or something with a sudden or violent movement
grab.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I grabbed my bag and ran off.
Two men grabbed her and pushed her to the ground.
Kay grabbed hold of my arm to stop herself falling.
I managed to grab the gun from Bowen.
grab.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to get some food or sleep quickly because you are busy
grab.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Why don’t you go and grab some sleep?
Hang on while I grab a cup of coffee.
Let’s grab a bite to eat before we go.
grab.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to get something for yourself, sometimes in an unfair way
grab.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Try to get there early and grab good seats.
Bob tried to grab all the profit.
grab.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to take an opportunity, accept an invitation etc immediately
grab.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I think you should grab your chance to travel while you’re young.
She grabbed the opportunity to go to America.
Melanie grabbed at the invitation to go.
This is our chance to grab a slice of this new market.
grab.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The book is full of good ideas to grab your students’ attention.
The plight of the refugees immediately grabbed the headlines (=was the most important story in the newspapers).
grab.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to take information on a computer, website etc
grab.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: the act of getting something quickly, especially in a dishonest way
grab.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: a shameless power grab to eliminate opposition
Officials denounced the settlers’ land grab.
grab.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to take or obtain something that other people also want
grab.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Both companies are looking to grab a share of the overseas market.
grab.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: an attempt to take or obtain something that other people also want
grab.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The company’s recent growth could slow if competitors make a grab for some of its markets.
British and Spanish officials complain that the idea looks suspiciously like a power-grab by Brussels  (=an attempt by Brussels to get power over something).
grab.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: if something is up for grabs, it is available for anyone who wants to try to obtain it
grab.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: Argentina has already sold off its telephone company, and dozens of other assets are up for grabs.
A large part of the business might be put up for grabs.
